texts: The long time standard for the Prime Meridian has been located in this British town. Despite naming a time zone notated “zero” in Coordinated Universal Time, the meridian in this town is actually 123 meters east of the Prime Meridian’s most recent calculation.

bonuses.formatted_leadin: The platform Moral Machine was created by MIT Media Lab to help autonomous vehicles with this scenario. For 10 points each:
texts: Name this thought experiment in which you have to decide whom to kill by a switchtrack for the namesake runaway vehicle.

If you have the choice to switch a track for a runaway trolley heading towards a group of five murderers so that it instead kills one innocent bystander, proponents of this ethical theory like Henry Sidgwick would say that it is obligatory to switch the track regardless of innocence, because five is greater than one.

The choice to push a fat man into the track to stop the trolley and save five lives at the expense of one explores this principle, which states that you may take action which has bad side effects, but deliberately intending harm is wrong even if for good causes.

This leading musician of the bebop era played alto saxophone on “Shaw ‘Nuff.” He is also known for his pieces “Crazeology,” “Ko-Ko,” and “Ornithology.”

The chord structure of “Crazeology” consists of the namesake “changes” based on this song by George Gershwin. It consists of a thirty-two bar A-B-B-A form with the chords I, vi, ii, V [“one, six, two, five”] followed by a circle of fourths.

bonuses.formatted_leadin: Answer some questions about the language of the Pirahã [pee-duh-HA] people in the Amazon, for 10 points each:
texts: Study of the language of the Pirahãs has caused many to reevaluate the Universal Grammar proposed by this MIT linguist, since it does not contain numbers, past or future tenses, recursion, or other supposedly ubiquitous concepts included in this man’s work Syntactic Structures.

The Pirahã language is believed to have either ten or eleven of these fundamental units of sound that do not convey meaning by themselves. Those consist of three vowels and either seven or eight consonants.

In transcribing the Pirahã language, an “x” is used to denote this phoneme that is produced by abruptly obstructing airflow through the entrance of the vocal folds. In English, this phoneme occurs in the interjection “uh-oh” and can be used in place of a “t” in the words “cat” and “button.”

This enzyme catalyzes the first major step of carbon fixation in the Calvin cycle. It uses ATP and NADPH to break six-carbon molecules into two equal parts, and it is the most abundant protein on Earth.

answers: golden ratio [or divine proportion or medial section; prompt on an approximation like 1.618]

These two scientists proved that DNA is the primary vehicle of genetic information through their namesake experiment conducted in 1952, in which bacteriophages infected bacterial cells with DNA and not primarily proteins.

Conjugation, a form of horizontal gene transfer that connects two bacteria via a pilus, transports this plasmid, which contains specific replication genes and tra genes, despite not being necessary for bacterial function. In E. Coli, it is known as the sex factor.
answers: Alfred Hershey and Martha Chase [both parts required]

Conjugation, a form of horizontal gene transfer that connects two bacteria via a pilus, transports this plasmid, which contains specific replication genes and tra genes, despite not being necessary for bacterial function. In E. Coli, it is known as the sex factor.

texts: Identify this formula that describes the relationship between angles of incident light and refracted light. It can be derived from Fermat’s principle of least time.

When light traveling into a medium of lower refractive index is incident at this angle, the refracted ray has an angle of ninety degrees. This is the angle past which incident light will experience total internal reflection instead of refraction.

Snell’s Law can be used to determine that Brewster’s angle--the angle of incidence at which polarized light experiences no reflection--is equal to this function of the quotient of final and initial materials’ refractive indices.
answers: arctangent or inverse tangent [do not accept “tangent”] <Wenzer Qin>/<ed. Seth Ebner>

texts: Several years prior to the start of the war, Haber developed a process to produce this compound. Domestic production of this compound helped free Germany from reliance on foreign nitrate deposits.

During the War, Haber led German weaponization of this gas, which can itself be reacted with carbon monoxide to produce phosgene, another war gas.

texts: Name this operation, shown to be the inverse of differentiation by the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus.

If you cut up a curve into lots of contiguous rectangles, then find the cumulative area of the rectangles, you’ve done a type of integration named for this German mathematician. This type of integration should not be confused with Lebesgue integration.
Integration can be used to find that this figure, formed by rotation of the curve “1 divided by x from x equals 1 to x equals infinity” around the x-axis, has infinite surface area but finite volume.
answers: integration [or word forms, such as finding the integral]

This complementary phenomenon occurs when the source is moving away from the observer. Cosmological examples of this phenomenon serve as evidence that our universe is expanding.
Both blueshift and redshift are examples of this change in a wave’s frequency due to its relative motion. Sirens on moving vehicles are common examples of this effect.
answers: it decreases [or lessens; or goes down; accept equivalents]

texts: Name this character, whose “Fortunes and Misfortunes” are described in a novel that describes her five marriages, including once to her half-brother.
This author of Moll Flanders and A Journal of the Plague Year is most famous for a novel about a shipwrecked man inspired by Alexander Selkirk.
This Defoe novel was inspired by the story of Alexander Selkirk. The title character of this novel is taken to Sallee by pirates and rescues Friday from cannibals.
answers: Moll Flanders [or Moll Flanders; or The Fortunes and Misfortunes of the Famous Moll Flanders, etc. Who Was Born in Newgate, and During a Life of Continu’d Variety for Threescore Years, Besides her Childhood, was Twelve Year a Whore, Five Times a Wife (Whereof Once to her Own Brother), Twelve Year a Thief, Eight Year a Transported Felon in Virginia, at Last Grew Rich, Liv’d Honest, and Died a Penitent. Written from her Own Memorandums.]

Robinson Crusoe [The Life and Strange Surprizing Adventures of Robinson Crusoe, of York, Mariner: Who Lived Eight and Twenty Years, All Alone in an Un-inhabited Island on the Coast of America, Near the Mouth of the Great River of Oroonoque; Having Been Cast on Shore by Shipwreck, Wherein All the Men Perished but Himself. With an Account how he was at last as Strangely Deliver’d by Pyrates. Written by Himself.] <Carrie Derner>/<ed.Jacob>

answers: Hanukkah [or Chanukah; or Hanukah; or Feast of Lights; or Feast of Dedication; or Feast of the Maccabees]

texts: Identify these explosions of massive stars that occur at the end of a star’s lifetime. They are sometimes caused by sudden gravitational collapse.

This Prussian baron drilled the Continental Army into shape at Valley Forge before writing his “Blue Book,” which was a drill manual that helped to professionalize the army.
This Polish military engineer created defenses for the Americans at the Battle of Saratoga. He led a namesake uprising against Russia during the Third Partition of Poland.
answers: The Marquis de Lafayette [Marie-Joseph-Paul-Yves-Roch-Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette]
Baron Friedrich von Steuben [Baron Friedrich Wilhelm Ludolf Gerhard Augustin von Steuben; or Frederick William Augustus, Freiherr von Steuben]
Tadeusz Kosciuszko (“Ko-shooz-ko”) [Andrzej Tadeusz Bonawentura Kosciuszko] <Owen Pasley>/<ed. Jacob>
formatted_texts: This French nobleman served as George Washington’s aide-de-camp. This “Hero of Two Worlds” was wounded at Brandywine and helped to close off Cornwallis’ escape at Yorktown.
This Prussian baron drilled the Continental Army into shape at Valley Forge before writing his “Blue Book,” which was a drill manual that helped to professionalize the army.
This Polish military engineer created defenses for the Americans at the Battle of Saratoga. He led a namesake uprising against Russia during the Third Partition of Poland.
formatted_answers: The Marquis de Lafayette [Marie-Joseph-Paul-Yves-Roch-Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette]
Baron Friedrich von Steuben [Baron Friedrich Wilhelm Ludolf Gerhard Augustin von Steuben; or Frederick William Augustus, Freiherr von Steuben]

texts: Name this type of bonding in which electrons are shared between atoms.
This rule states that bonds tend to give the atoms of a compound exactly eight valence electrons. In the case of hydrogen and helium, it is replaced with a simpler “duet” rule.

This diatomic compound, with formula NO, violates the octet rule, as its two atoms only combine to have seven valence electrons. In a famous accident, Sir Humphry Davy inhaled this reactive gas, which combined with the common air to form nitric acid in his mouth.
answers: Nitric oxide or Nitrogen monoxide (do not accept nitrous oxide or laughing gas)

texts: Every tile in the game will display one of these numbers. The smallest examples of these numbers -- and, therefore, the earliest numbers seen in the game -- are 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32.

answers: Bernhard Riemann (accept Riemann hypothesis, Riemann conjecture, Riemann sum, Riemann integral, etc.)

This event, the creation of heavier-than-hydrogen elements like helium-4 and lithium-7, took place within minutes after the Big Bang. This term can also refer to the creation of elements within stars.
answers: age of the Universe (accept clear knowledge equivalents)
Big Bang (or primordial) nucleosynthesis (accept stellar nucleosynthesis; prompt on "nuclear fusion")

texts: Name this author of the novel Matilda and James and the Giant Peach.
In this Roald Dahl novel, Augustus Gloop, Mike Teavee, and Violet Beauregarde are among the children who win a tour of the title, oompa-loompa-infested building.

This Dahl novel about a boy and his grandmother is named for people who “look very much like ordinary women,” but who “[hate] children with a red-hot sizzling hatred that is more sizzling and red-hot than any hatred you could possibly imagine.”
answers: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (do not accept “Willie Wonka and the Chocolate Factory”)

texts: Name this classic Parker Brothers board game in which you seek to buy properties like Park Place and Boardwalk.
A common house variation, but not an official Monopoly rule, is to award $500, or some other amount, to anyone who lands on this corner space between New York and Kentucky Avenues.

On television, the Simpsons own five versions of the game: "regular Monopoly, Star Wars Monopoly, Rasta-Mon-opoly, Galip-olopoly, and" one named for this character, Bart Simpson's 4th grade teacher. She was retired from the show when her voice actress, Marcia Wallace, passed away.
answers: Edna Krabappel-Flanders (accept either underlined name; accept Edna Krabappoly; be lenient and accept Krabappoly)

texts: Give the term for these inherited traits that enhance the survival of an organism in its environment. Larger brains and walking upright were such traits in human ancestors.
The almost identical adaptations seen in the bodies of dolphins and extinct ichthyosaurs result from this type of evolution in which unrelated species evolve in similar environments.
Convergent evolution among birds produced the now extinct North Atlantic great auk and these living flightless birds of Antarctica. Both groups had the same black-and-white color pattern.

texts: Name this theorem, which was claimed without proof by a Frenchman in the margins of a textbook in 1637. The aforementioned 150-page proof was finished by Andrew Wiles in 1995.
Fermat's Last Theorem is concerned with an equation that traditionally uses the letters a, b, c, and n, where n serves this role.
This is the smallest exponent n for which Fermat's Last Theorem states there is no solution; that is, Fermat’s Last Theorem says that the sum of two cubes cannot equal another cubic number.
answers: Fermat's Last Theorem (prompt on “Fermat’s Theorem;” do not accept Fermat’s little theorem)
the exponent (or power) of a, b, and c (accept answers describing "to the n power," such as "a to the n plus b to the n equals c to the n")

texts: Identify this author of The Prince and the Pauper. The title character of another of this man’s novels proposes to Becky Thatcher and witnesses his own funeral.

This Mark Twain character titles a novel in which he discovers hidden gold in a cave and proposes to Becky Thatcher by giving her a doorknob. He is the older brother of Sid, and is raised by Aunt Polly.
In this Twain short story, Simon Wheeler tells a story about the title animal, who is fed buckshot so it will lose a contest for Leonidas W. Smiley.
answers: Thomas “Tom” Sawyer (accept either underlined name; accept The Adventures of Tom Sawyer)
The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County (accept Jim Smiley and his Jumping Frog)

texts: Name this country on the Horn of Africa. It has been considered a failed state for its inability to control a civil war in its territory or piracy in its waters.
Al-Shabaab was ousted from this capital of Somalia in 2011.

[10] Though Somalia has clashed with this neighbor country in the past, they have recently collaborated on joint attacks against al-Shabaab, who attacked the Westgate Mall in this country's capital city of Nairobi in 2013.
